title: Parents Just Don't Understand
content:
Miranda had grown up in what felt like an eternal Renaissance faire. Her parents were Moonbeam and Cosmic Ray, though before their 1987 spiritual awakening in a Glastonbury field they were simply Margaret and James. Their Cotswolds cottage had been a revolving door of healing crystals, visiting shamans and neighbours who'd pop round to discuss Reiki over homemade kombucha. By age sixteen, Miranda could read tarot cards, knew which variety of sage could bless a room and had had her chakras realigned more times than a mystic with scoliosis.

It was for precisely this reason that she fell for Andy Hartwell. Seeing him on campus, a sensible Welsh boy studying architecture who wore collared shirts and used an inhaler[1], was like spotting a leather-clad, sleeve-tattooed biker revving his motorcycle outside the family home. He was her escape route into the forbidden world of processed foods and effective deodorant.

People usually chalked up her apparent rejection of her upbringing to rebellion for rebellion's sake. What could be better than being raised by such free-spirited parents? She felt like a child who ran away from the circus, to go to university and become a straight-laced accountant. Take that, Bearded Mum and World’s Strongest Dad. But our childhood beliefs can be difficult to quell. The leopard can’t change its spots; the accountant can’t help but juggle her stationery. Despite her best efforts, her mind and heart still clung to various cosmic notions of fate and Karma. Ewen's arrival and his logic-defying resurfacings was the final nudge sending her right back into the New Age pit she'd clawed out of.


Before she knew it, she had become the sort of person her younger self would have found insufferably authentic. The type who composted religiously and could discuss the merits of different yoga poses with the earnestness of a mystic who had been cured of his scoliosis. Andy, of course, had fallen in love with her all over again. His support was unwavering; bringing worms for the compost and forcing himself to relearn how to sit cross-legged, an ability he had lost in his teens.


The pottery wheel had been his last gift to her, ordered online two weeks before the accident but arriving three weeks after the funeral. She'd stared at the box for months before finally opening it. Inside, a giftcard message read “Now we can finally recreate that scene from Ghost. - A”  Despite the now-cruel irony, she couldn’t help but laugh. It was exactly what Andy would have quipped had he been standing right beside her. Today, her kitchen shelves were lined with wonky bowls and mugs, lopsided and bent over like they had eaten bad Taco Bell the night before. Ewen called them “Mum’s Tipoverware” and refused to drink his morning orange juice from anything else.


She was preparing supper in one of these very bowls when Ewen approached with a question. She listened patiently to his proposal, outwardly composed though caught off-guard. Her instinct was to shut it down, but part of her wondered if this would be good for him. Maybe he needed to go.


“So, Mum? What do you think?”


She hesitated, studying his small, eager face. He looked so much like Andy. “Sure, you can go.”


“Mum, you’re the best!!.” Ewen clamped his mother in a bear hug before sprinting out the kitchen door, leaving Miranda wondering what she had just done. 


Ewen ran to the front of the house where Maya had been waiting. “It worked!” he exclaimed excitedly. “She said yes!”


“I can’t believe you pulled it off!” Maya beamed. “Maybe you really are a spy after all.”


“"High five to that jive!" he replied, regretting it immediately. “That’s one parent down, one to go. What’s the plan for your Mum?”


“We have to make her believe it was her idea,” Maya warned. “Ma can be kind of headstrong.”


Ewen’s eyes widened. Maya calling someone headstrong was like when ISIS first started and Al-Qaeda put out a press release saying “Yo, these guys are crazy.” And everyone was like “They’re crazy? You’re Al-Qaeda!” And they were like “C’moon, we just did the regular stuff. These guys beheadin’ down a dangerous path. Eh? Eh? Am I right? Hey is anyone sitting here, what were you guys talking about?” And we were like “They make us take our shoes off at airports because of you! We've told you before to stop with the puns, Al-Qaeda, we're not friends like that. And Kerry and Dale were sitting there but Kerry had to go get her Epi-Pen because there were peanuts in her sauce.” And they were like “I’ve got an Epi-Pen in my thela, she could have asked me. Do you guys want to come over later? My cousin left his DVD of Carmen Electra workouts if you want to- hey, guys, where are you going? I’ll come with, just let me take this vest off! Death to Ameri- I mean, wait up!”


Her mum must be proper headstrong.



In Malaysia, she'd been Jasleen Gill: civil engineer, weekend cricket umpire and member of an all-female rock band called the Crockettes known throughout her village. But the moment her soles touched the Cardiff airport tarmac, all of that ceased to matter. In an instant, she became little more than the new Asian lady in town. The transition had been harder than she had anticipated. Not the language, she'd grown up speaking English alongside Punjabi and Malay (was this where Maya got her love of foreign swear words?). It wasn’t even the Welsh weather, which I believe I have mentioned two or three thousand times already. It was the invisibility that surprised her.


The first weeks alone in their small rental while her family ventured into new lives felt like several lifetimes. But one day, some idle Tuesday, she decided that enough was enough. She could either cry over spilt milk, or keep busy while the spilt milk curdled, then went rancid, then started smelling like Death Himself had vomited in a rotting trash can, and then finally, inexplicably, became cheese.[2] She circled job postings in that morning's classifieds and was hired within a fortnight. 


Work was a revelation. She quickly discovered being a crossing guard was like being the mayor of a very small, mobile city. She knew which children were plotting to skip school, which teachers were entangled in various trysts and whose un-newtered dog was responsible for the new litter of puppies at number forty-seven. She also learned the best way to withstand hours of Welsh rain was to simply imagine she was back in Sabah, standing directly under the Mahua waterfall fully clothed and for some reason holding a giant stop sign. The role gave her a community and purpose. She never tired of hearing children and parents call her Miss Jazz. Most importantly, she no longer felt invisible. In fact, she felt more seen than ever, though to be fair she did wear a fluro-yellow vest. 


Now folding laundry in the front room, she heard Maya's footsteps on the path outside. Peering through the window, she saw Ewen trailing behind and smiled. Despite what many parents thought of him (you’d be surprised what people discussed when crossing the street[3]), she always held a fondness for the quirky boy. He was bright, well-mannered and had forged a deep bond with Maya and Hari. Jasleen was a firm believer that the occasional speaking in tongues or graphic ancient ritual sacrifice shouldn't stand in the way of true camaraderie. She had also formed an unlikely friendship with Miranda. When the Singh’s first arrived in Bridgend, Miranda had been overzealous in assuming that a woman from Asia would naturally share her newfound spiritual interests. Jasleen, with her analytical mind and practical worldview, had gently corrected this misconception. But after Andy’s accident when Miranda needed a tangible shoulder to cry on rather than vague cosmic platitudes, Jasleen showed up and never left. Their friendship was the sort cobbled together from impromptu dinners, emergency school drop offs and the comfortable silence of two mothers who understood loss.


Maya had now wandered into the room, settling herself at the edge of the bed with the sort of nonchalance that immediately put her mother on high alert. "Ma,” she began, “you know what's really unfair?".


"What's unfair, beta?" Jasleen asked, knowing full well she was about to find out whether she wanted to or not. 


"Well, it's just that Ewen has this whole other family he's never met. Like, he has this uncle in Paris who probably knows all these stories about his Dad that he's never heard. And he's just... stuck in Wales with us boring people."


"We are not boring," Jasleen said mildly. "And there are plenty of interesting people from Wales.”

"Name one."

"Tom Jones."[4]

Maya laughed. "You can’t just put two white people's names together and expect that to work." She sighed deeply, maybe a little too deeply. “I just feel sad that he might lose that part of himself. Besides, I kind of know how he feels. I wish I could learn more about my culture as well.”

Now Jasleen laughed. “You act more Welsh than most kids in your school. I didn’t think you cared at all about where we came from.”

Maya thought about the pressed flowers under her mattress, and bit her tongue. She looked at her mother; a woman as hard as the desert but as soft as the sand, who had forged a new life for herself half a world away. She chose her words carefully.

"I just think," Maya said, as solemn as Caruso standing over a still warm corpse, "that sometimes we need to go places to figure out where we belong."[5]


Joseph Hartwell stood at the arrivals hall of Paris Gare du Nord, clutching a hand-drawn sign that read "EWEN" in letters large enough to be read from Bridgend. He was twenty minutes early, partly from nervousness and partly because he'd never collected a child before and had no idea how it worked. Was that even the right word, collected?

The 14:47 from London was due in three minutes. He found himself muttering his prepared speech for the hundredth time. "Hello, Ewen, I'm your Uncle Joseph. And you must be Maya. Bienvenue à Paris. Look how you’ve grown. Did you have a good journey? Are you hungry? Do you need the loo?" Wait, was that too many questions? Why was he only realising this now?

Miranda had called three days ago, catching him completely off-guard. They’d barely  spoken a dozen times since the funeral. When her name flashed across his phone, he was sure it was a butt dial.

"Joseph," she'd said, cutting straight to the chase, "Ewen wants to come visit you in Paris."

"Miranda, hi. Wait, Ewen wants to... what?"

"Visit you. In Paris. For a few days. Sorry. I know it's sudden, but he's been talking about it non-stop lately. Honestly, I think it might be good for him. To reconnect with your side of the family, you know?"

A thousand thoughts reeled through his mind, like when you use your Mum’s phone and she has like forty different apps open and two hundred uncleared notifications and god, Mum, why is your phone running so hot, are you on Temu again?

"I... sure, yes, of course," he'd heard himself saying. "When were you thinking?"

"This weekend? I know it's short notice, but summer holidays and all that." A pause now, then more gently. "He's very excited." How could he say no?

Joseph had spent the next three days in a mild panic. Nine years in Paris as a chronically single thirty-four year old left him with no clue about what the city might offer a child. He had turned to online research, learning both about Paris but also children in general. He was embarrassed to admit one of his Google searches even included “child food”, as if kid’s meals were sold the same way as kibble or bird seed.[6] Ultimately, he’d stocked his refrigerator with various brands of chicken nuggets and chocolate milk, and called it a day.

The train pulled in with a hiss of brakes and general commotion of disembarking passengers. Joseph held his sign higher and scanned the crowd for a small boy who would look like Andy. This was the part he'd been dreading. Seeing Andy's features in miniature, alive and animated in a way both wonderful and heartbreaking, like the custom-made bobble head I bought for my wife after couples therapy.

People assumed being fraternal twins meant they were alike, but sharing a birthday was where Joseph and Andy's similarities ended. Joseph had been the tall one, Andy the short one. Andy supported Manchester United with Taylor Swift stan fanaticism, while Joseph's Liverpool allegiance was worn lightly, like those paper underwear they give you for massages. Where Joseph drifted through life like a plastic bag in the wind, like in that Katy Perry song, Andy roared and danced through the fire of life, like in that other Katy Perry song. Andy had been the rock, the Dwayne Johnson, that gave Joseph the courage to live whimsically. Since he'd gone, Joseph found himself second-guessing everything, as if Andy's absence had stolen not just his brother but his own ability to navigate the world without worry.

The crowd thinned. A few latecomers hurried past, dragging suitcases and checking phones. Still no nephew. Joseph lowered his sign and checked his watch. Perhaps the boy was confused, or needed help with luggage. A conductor walked the train length, checking compartments. Nothing. Something cold settled in his stomach. Eventually, Joseph was alone on the platform, holding his ridiulous sign and trying to make sense of what had gone wrong. Mix-up with tickets? Had Ewen changed his mind? Something worse? Panic rose in his chest (he had seen Taken 2) when mercifully his phone buzzed.  A text from an unknown number: "Hi Uncle Joe,” it began.  

Joseph stared at the message for an age before putting his phone away. He felt completely at sea, a feeling he had become accustomed to where his brother's family was concerned. He carefully made his way back through the station toward the ticketing office. Joseph caught his reflection in a shop window, a man holding a forlorn sign, looking lost in his own city. Worry tugged at his ankles like the receding tide, threatening to upset his footing and drag him back into the churning waters of his brother’s absence.

footnotes.content: She had planned to walk over to him and drop the line, “I love that you use Western medicine.” Luckily, fate had intervened and he had approached her first with the equally flirtatious line, "Hello."
Hey, what's with that?

Why is that Ewen kid so strange? Does your face look better in the mirror than on your selfie camera too? What if Gandalf the Grey became the illest rapper in all of Middle Earth and tried to play the New York Times online game Spelling Bee

One of the biggest sources of friction in my marriage is my habit of vocalising whatever I’m doing in the form of parody songs. Once we were on the way to a party and I wanted to check if my friend Tom was still coming. As I messaged him, I sang the following song to the tune of Sex Bomb, by Tom Jones:

Text Tom, text Tom, gonna text Tom.

If he says he isn’t going I will punch him in the dong.

Text Tom, text Tom, gonna text Tom.

Hoping I don’t touch his dong.

Our couple’s therapist says the last line indicates I may secretly want to touch Tom’s dong. This is not true.
